data.title: Bengaluru Metro Orange Line Overview
data.meta_description: Explore Bengaluru's Orange Line metro – your gateway to hassle-free and eco-friendly transportation in the city. Start your journey today!
data.text:
Interested In Buying A Property? Click Here!

Check Out Some Properties In Bengaluru

Introduction

In the ever-growing city of Bengaluru, where busy streets and rapid urban development define the city's character, having an efficient and easy-to-use public transportation system is incredibly important for sustainable growth. That's where the Bengaluru Metro comes in. It's a forward-thinking project that is not only changing how people get around the city but also influencing the way the city itself is evolving.

In this article, we'll focus on a special part of the metro system: the highly anticipated Bengaluru Metro Orange Line. As a city that depends on good transportation, the Orange Line is going to be a big deal for Bengaluru. It will have a network of stations strategically placed in important areas, and it's an elevated track that will change how people travel around the city.

Let's dive into the specifics and see how this ambitious project is guiding Bengaluru towards a future with smooth transportation and city growth.

Next Phase Of Namma Metro

Image Source: iStock

Recent developments have brought forth an exciting expansion to the Namma Metro project, designed to further enhance Bengaluru's connectivity and ease of travel.

The upcoming Phase 3A of the Namma Metro initiative is all set to cover an extensive distance of 44.65 kilometres, encompassing two distinct corridors. The total financial outlay for this advancement is estimated at Rs 16,328 crore, with a targeted completion year of 2028.

In the third phase of the project, two road-cum-metro flyovers are also set to be built. The first one will span 1.366 kilometres, connecting Kanakapura Road junction to Sarakki junction. The second flyover, measuring 1.563 kilometres, will link Kamakya – Ittamadu – Hoskerehalli junctions.

Corridor Overview

Corridor One (32.15 km) (Orange Line): This corridor forms a pivotal stretch along the Outer Ring Road (ORR) West, connecting JP Nagar 4th Phase to Kempapura, with 22 stations. Among these, eight stations will serve as interchange points, including two junctions integrated with railway stations: BEL Circle and Hebbal.

Corridor Two (12.50 km) (Unnamed Line): The second corridor spans 12.50 km along Magadi Road, from Hosahalli to Kadabagere, encompassing nine stations. Two interchange points are slated for this corridor: Hosahalli and Sumanahalli Cross. So, in total there are 9 stations in the second corridor.

Financial Breakdown

Image Source: iStock

Government Contribution: The state government's involvement includes bearing 20 per cent of the project expenses, as well as funding property acquisition costs.

Central Involvement: The central government is expected to contribute 20 per cent of the project costs.

BMRCL's Role: The Bengaluru Metro Rail Corporation Limited (BMRCL) will assume responsibility for the remaining 60 per cent of the project expenditure, amounting to Rs 7,577 crore. This financing will be facilitated through external assistance, including debts and private funding.

Significance Of The Orange Line In Urban Mobility

Here are some of the reasons why the Bengaluru Metro Orange Line is significant in urban mobility:

Reduce traffic congestion: The Orange Line is expected to reduce traffic congestion on the roads of Bengaluru by providing an alternative mode of transportation. According to a study by the World Bank, traffic congestion in Bengaluru costs the city an estimated Rs. 1,400 crore (US$180 million) per year in terms of lost productivity and fuel costs. The Orange Line is expected to reduce traffic congestion by up to 20%.

Improve connectivity: The Orange Line will improve connectivity between different parts of Bengaluru, making it easier for people to get around. This will be especially beneficial for people who live in the IT hub of Whitefield, as the Orange Line will provide them with a direct connection to the city centre.

Boost the economy: The Orange Line is expected to boost the economy of Bengaluru by attracting new businesses and jobs. The line will make it easier for businesses to operate in Bengaluru, as they will have better access to their customers and employees. The line is also expected to create jobs during its construction and operation.

Reduce pollution: The Orange Line is expected to reduce pollution in Bengaluru by taking cars off the road. According to a study by the Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, road transport accounts for about 30% of the city's air pollution. The Orange Line is expected to reduce this pollution by up to 10%.

Promote sustainable transportation: The Orange Line is a sustainable form of transportation, as it uses electricity instead of fossil fuels. This will help to reduce Bengaluru's reliance on fossil fuels and improve the city's air quality.

Overall, the Bengaluru Metro Orange Line is a significant project that will have a positive impact on the city's urban mobility. The line will help to reduce traffic congestion, improve connectivity, boost the economy, reduce pollution, and promote sustainable transportation.

Key Details Of The Orange Line

Image Source: iStock

Bengaluru's journey towards better connectivity takes a significant leap with the soon-to-arrive Orange Line. Familiarly known as the ORR-West Line, this proposed addition to the city's metro system is set to redefine how Bengaluruans navigate their bustling metropolis.

Status: Currently under construction, the Orange Line is a planned project, poised to elevate Bengaluru's transportation options.

Ownership: Under the jurisdiction of the Bengaluru Metro Rail Corporation Limited (BMRCL), a local entity dedicated to enhancing urban mobility.

Location: Designed to intricately weave through the city's streets, spanning Bengaluru in Karnataka, India.

Route: Extending from JP Nagar IV Phase (JD Mall) to Kempapura, facilitating efficient travel between these key points.

Stations: The Orange Line will encompass a total of 22 stations on Corridor I and an additional 9 stations on Corridor II, creating an extensive web of accessible stops.

Website: For more information, interested individuals can visit the official website at bmrc.co.in.

Type: Classified as a metro, the Orange Line falls within the umbrella of the Namma Metro system.

Depot(s): The locations for depots are yet to be determined, an indication of the ongoing planning and commitment to a well-designed system.

Planned Opening: Envisioned to be operational by 2028, the Orange Line's inauguration is just around the corner, promising enhanced mobility in the city.

Line Length: Covering an impressive distance of 31 kilometres, the Orange Line's reach aims to embrace various corners of Bengaluru.

Tracks: Equipped with a pair of tracks, this design ensures efficient and safe movement.

Character and Gauge: The specifics about the line's character are yet to be fully disclosed. The standard track gauge of 1,435 mm (4 ft 8+1⁄2 in) ensures compatibility with global rail systems.

Electrification: Powered by a 750 V DC third rail system, the Orange Line embodies modern and eco-friendly transportation practices.

As the Orange Line emerges on the horizon, it promises not only to ease the daily commute but also to enhance the fabric of Bengaluru's urban landscape, connecting neighbourhoods, businesses, and lives along the way.

Stations And Route Of The Orange Line

Image Source: iStock

The upcoming Orange Line is set to revolutionise commuting with its elevated route featuring 22 planned stations and interchange points. This innovative line spans a remarkable 31 kilometres along the Outer Ring Road, stretching from JP Nagar to Kempapura. Corridor II, on the other hand, is designed to extend from Hosahalli Toll to Kadabagere with 9 stations in total.

Proposed Stations And Intersections on Corridor-I :

JP Nagar IV Phase (JD Mall) (Pink Line)

JP Nagar V Phase

JP Nagar (Green Line)

Kadirenahalli

Kamakya Bus Depot

Hosakerahalli Cross

PES Institute of Technology

Mysuru Road (Purple Line)

Nagarbhavi Circle

Vinayaka Layout

Dr. Ambedkar Institute of Engineering

Nagarbhavi BDA Complex

Sumanahalli Cross (Hosahalli-Kadabagere Line)

Chowdeshwari Nagar

Freedom Fighters Cross

Kranteevera Studio

Peenya (Green Line)

Bahubali Nagar

BEL Circle

Patelappa Layout

Hebbal (Hebbala Suburban Railway Station)

Kempapura (Blue Line)

Proposed Stations and Intersections for Corridor II - Hosahalli-Kadabagere Line

Hosahalli (Purple Line)

K H B Colony

Vinayaka Nagara

Sumanahalli Cross (Orange Line)

Sunkadakatte

Herohalli

Bydarahalli

Forest Gate

Kadabagere

Strategically placed along the route, these stations aim to provide seamless connectivity and effortless transfers between various transportation modes. As the Orange Line commences operations, it's not just a mode of travel; it's the city's lifeline, shaping a smarter, eco-friendly, and more interconnected urban future.

Connecting Major Areas Of Bengaluru

Image Source: iStock

Here are some of the major areas in Bengaluru that will be connected by the Orange Line:

JP Nagar: JP Nagar is a residential and commercial area in the east of Bengaluru. It is home to many IT companies and educational institutions.

Hosahalli: Hosahalli is a residential area in the east of Bengaluru. It is located near the Outer Ring Road and is well-connected to other parts of the city.

Marathalli: Marathhalli is a commercial area in the east of Bengaluru. It is home to many IT companies and is well-connected to the rest of the city.

Iblur: Iblur is a residential area in the east of Bengaluru. It is located near the Outer Ring Road and is well-connected to other parts of the city.

Whitefield: Whitefield is an IT hub in the east of Bengaluru. It is home to many IT companies and is well-connected to other parts of the city.

Banashankari: Banashankari is a residential area in the east of Bengaluru. It is well-connected to other parts of the city by road and metro.

HAL Airport Road: HAL Airport Road is a major road in the east of Bengaluru. It connects the city to the Kempegowda International Airport.

Hebbal: Hebbal is a commercial area in the west of Bengaluru. It is well-connected to other parts of the city by road and metro.

Peenya: Peenya is an industrial area in the west of Bengaluru. It is well-connected to other parts of the city by road and metro.

The Orange Line will connect these major areas of Bengaluru, making it easier for people to get around the city. The line will also help to reduce traffic congestion and improve air quality.

Bengaluru Metro Phase And Expected Completion

Image Source: iStock

Here is some information about the proposed phase and duration of the Bengaluru Metro Orange Line:

Proposed Phase: The Orange Line is part of Phase 3A of the Bengaluru Metro project. Phase 3A consists of two lines, the Orange Line and an unnamed Line.

Duration: The construction of the Orange Line is expected to take 5 years. The line is expected to be operational by 2028.

This eagerly awaited addition to the city's metro network is not only expected to transform commuting but is also geared to seamlessly connect with the extended Corridor-II, offering interchange facilities at key depots and bustling business centres.

Real Estate Impact Due To The Orange Line

Image Source: iStock

Increased property values: The metro is expected to increase property values in the areas around the stations. This is because the metro will make these areas more accessible and desirable, and it will also reduce traffic congestion.

Increased demand for housing: The metro is expected to increase the demand for housing in the areas around the stations. This is because the metro will make it more convenient for people to live in these areas, and it will also attract new businesses and jobs.

Improved connectivity: The metro will improve connectivity between different parts of the city, which will make it easier for people to get around. This is expected to boost the real estate market in the city as a whole.

Attraction for investors: The metro is expected to attract investors to the real estate market in Bengaluru. This is because the metro is a sign of development and progress, and it is also seen as a safe investment.

However, it is important to note that the impact of the metro on the real estate market will depend on a number of factors, such as the location of the stations, the quality of the metro service, and the overall economic conditions.

Here are some of the areas that are expected to be most affected by the Bengaluru Metro Orange Line:

JP Nagar: JP Nagar is a residential and commercial area in the east of Bengaluru. It is home to many IT companies and educational institutions. The metro will connect JP Nagar to the city centre and other parts of the city, making it a more attractive place to live and work.

Whitefield: Whitefield is an IT hub in the east of Bengaluru. It is home to many IT companies and is well-connected to other parts of the city. The metro will further improve the connectivity of Whitefield and make it an even more attractive place for businesses and residents.

Hebbal: Hebbal is a commercial area in the west of Bengaluru. It is well-connected to other parts of the city by road and metro. The metro will further improve the connectivity of Hebbal and make it an even more attractive place for businesses and residents.

Overall, the Bengaluru Metro Orange Line is expected to have a positive impact on the real estate market in the city. The metro will increase property values, boost demand for housing, improve connectivity, and attract investors. However, the actual impact of the metro will depend on a number of factors, and it is important to do your own research before investing in real estate in Bengaluru.

Final Word
